data.title: RAAF WWII Roll of Honour for Fighter Units – Aviation Heritage Museum
data.text:
On 15 February 1942, Lieutenant Robert J Buel (O-424901) flying a Kittyhawk from Darwin was lost in the Arafura Sea to the north east of Darwin while flying in support of a convoy enroute to Timor. The only other Kittyhawk then at Darwin was on another patrol being flown by Second Lieutenant Robert G Oestreicher DSC (O-421298).

On 19 February 1942, 10 Kittyhawk aircraft, that had arrived in Darwin around midday on 15 February, set out from Darwin for Timor but turned back due to poor weather. On return to Darwin, Major Floyd Joaquin Pell DSC (O-20701), the Commanding Officer ordered five aircraft to be led by Second Lieutenant Oestreicher (the only other experienced pilot) to remain on Combat Air Patrol over the harbour while the other five aircraft were to be refuelled.

While on patrol, Second Lieutenant Oestreicher sighted the first wave of Japanese aircraft about to begin their attack and warned Major Pell over the radio. Four of the aircraft on patrol were shot down and two pilots were killed.

– Second Lieutenant Jack R Peres DSC (O-416707) was pursued and shot down by two aircraft and crashed in bush east of Darwin and was killed.

– Second Lieutenant Elton Stacy Perry DSC (O-425042) was shot down into the sea and was killed.

– Second Lieutenant Max R Wiecks DSC (O-430006) bailed out into the sea and was rescued.

– Second Lieutenant William R Walker DSC (18034009), though injured, crash landed his Kittyhawk at the RAAF Station.

– Having shot down at least one aircraft and out of ammunition, Second Lieutenant Oestreicher flew south at treetop level towards Daly River and landed there safely.

Refuelling had been completed for the five aircraft and on receiving Oestreicher’s warning, they all were scrambled. All five were shot down and two pilots were killed. In total, the aerial battle lasted about 10 minutes and from then and during the second raid later that day, there was no aerial opposition to the Japanese forces.

– Second Lieutenant Charles W Hughes (O-427738) was strafed during take off at Darwin and died in his aircraft in a crash near the RAAF Station.

– Major Pell has his Kittyhawk aircraft damaged by gunfire during aerial combat and he was forced to bale out too low for his parachute to deploy. He was then shot by cannon fire from another fighter aircraft and killed.

– Second Lieutenant Robert F McMahon DSC (O-427435)’s aircraft was damaged in aerial combat and he parachuted to safety near Waterlilly Creek south of Darwin.

– Second Lieutenant Burt H Rice DSC successfully baled from his aircraft that was damaged in aerial combat.

– Second Lieutenant John G Glover DSC (17017143) crash landed his aerial-combat damaged aircraft at the RAAF Station and was injured.

The air defence of Darwin was taken over by the USAAF’s 49th Fighter Group during March 1942. (See Fighter Groups and Wings)

CASUALTY DETAILS

On 10 September 1942, Aircraftman Class I Leonard Clarence Doughton (1154106) (RAFVR) died in India while in transit to Australia.

On 25 November 1942, Sergeant William Kenneth Read (656769) (RAF) was killed when Spitfire Capstan BS165 crashed while making a forced landing at Cattai Creek, New South Wales.

On 5 February 1943, Sergeant Peter Frederick McCarthy (1271615) (RAFVR) was killed, when during landing at RAAF Station Darwin, Spitfire A58-41 collided with Spitfire A58-11 being flown by Sergeant Cooper.

On 15 March 1943, Sergeant Albert Edward Cooper (940030) (RAFVR) in Spitfire AR620 was killed in aerial combat over Darwin and his aircraft crashed into the sea.

On 16 March 1943, Sergeant Francis Leslie Varney (142861) (RAFVR) flying Spitfire AR619 died from wounds received in aerial combat the previous day.

On 30 June 1943, Pilot Officer John Charles Wellsman (142859) (RAFVR) flying Spitfire BR528 was killed in aerial combat over Darwin.

On 7 September 1943, Flying Officer William Torrence Hinds (129948) flying Spitfire EF558 was killed in aerial combat while a intercepting a heavily protected reconnaissance aircraft near Darwin.

On 13 January 1944, Flight Sergeant James Basil Gibbs (1320096) (RAFVR) was killed near Strauss when Spitfire A58-63 collided with Spitfire A58-214 being flown by Flight Sergeant Whalley.

On 13 January 1944, Flight Sergeant John Hoyle Whalley (173288) (RAFVR) was killed near Strauss when Spitfire A58-214 collided with Spitfire A58-63 being flown by Flight Sergeant Gibbs.

On 18 April 1944, Flying Officer Peter George Fleming Brown (120926) (RAFVR) was killed during a ferry flight when Spitfire A58-309 experienced engine problems and caught fire in the resulting forced landing near Katherine.

On 28 July 1944, Flight Lieutenant Frederick Meakin (123140) (RAFVR) was killed during formation practice when Spitfire A58-390 struck trees and crashed just after take-off at Hughes Airstrip, Northern Territory.

On 5 October 1944, Pilot Officer Peter Fox (188187) (1119366) (RAFVR) was killed during an aircraft acceptance check when Spitfire A58-310 carried out a power dive, was pulled out too low, did a high speed stall and crashed into the sea.

On 3 March 1945, Leading Aircraftman Charles Simmons (1253692) (RAFVR) died of an illness at Sydney, New South Wales.

On 17 June 1945, Flying Officer Frederick Francis Thomas (155264) (RAFVR) was killed during an air test when Spitfire A58-479 caught fire in the air and he was likely overcome by fumes as the aircraft dived vertically into the ground at RAAF Station Darwin.

Roll of HONOUR: 49TH FIGHTER GROUP USAAF, DARWIN – MARCH TO SEPTEMBER 1942

The 49th Fighter Group USAAC comprised 5 Squadrons – Headquarters, 7, 8, 9 Pursuit and Interceptor Control Squadron.

On 17 March 1942 Second Lieutenant Albert L Spehr (19038740) was killed during the test flight of a Kittyhawk aircraft at Daly Waters on the transit to Darwin.

On 4 April 1942, Second Lieutenant John Dick Livingstone Jr’s (12005654) aircraft was hit by gunfire during a Japanese Raid and he was killed when the aircraft crashed while landing at the 34 Mile Airstrip (later named Livingstone).

On 21 April 1942 ten members of the Interceptor Control Squadron, 49th Fighter Group were killed when a chartered aircraft (Pilot: Flight Lieutenant Duncan Gordon Cameron (287418)) in which they were travelling crashed on Annaburro Station, Northern Territory. The USAAF servicemen killed were:

Corporal Bill Bedford (member unable to be further identified)

Private First Class John J Faris (06944576)

Private First Class Walter M Feret (16035030)

Corporal Anthony A Gattamelata (15069706)

Private First Class Robert W George (37082942)

Private First Class Nicholas L Hinch (39602442)

Private First Class Raymond R Love (18025425)

Private First Class Richard D Schmidt (16046323)

Private First Class Wyatt H Wyley (06794725)

Private First Class Buford H Willard (38003333)

On 25 April 1942, a US serviceman was reported killed during an air raid on Darwin. After shooting down a bomber on 25 April 1942, Lieutenant Sims made a forced landing on Bathurst Island and was rescued in the succeeding days and this event is possibley to have been recorded as the loss.

On 27 April 1942, Captain Allison W Strauss was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft was hit by gunfire in aerial combat and stalled and plunged into Darwin Harbour.

On 27 April 1942, Second Lieutenant Owen R Fish (O-429389) was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft was hit by gunfire in aerial combat and caught fire and plunged into Darwin Harbour.

On 29 April 1942, Time-Life Reporter and War Correspondent Melvin Jacoby and Second Lieutenant Robert D Jasper (15018914) were killed observing Kittyhawk aircraft taking-off when one swerved and struck a C-40 aircraft next to which they were standing. General Hal George also observing was fatally injured and died the following day and a number of other observers were injured.

On 6 June 1942, Second Lieutenant Edward M Miller (13027163) was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft crashed near Livingstone Airstrip. He was testing oxygen equipment and is believed to have lost consciousness.

On 9 June 1942, Second Lieutenant William H Payne (15018921) was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft crashed at Brock’s Creek. He was also testing oxygen equipment and is also believed to have lost consciousness.

On 16 June 1942, Lieutenant Chester T Namola (O-430937) was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft was hit by gunfire in aerial combat and spiralled into Darwin Harbour.

On 23 June 1942, Lieutenant Arthur E Fielder (14042204) was killed when his Kittyhawk aircraft stalled and crashed near Livingstone Airstrip during aerobatics practice.

On 12 July 1942, a Kittyhawk aircraft flown by Second Lieutenant John S Sauber (17018228) collided with a Kittyhawk aircraft flown by Second Lieutenant George E Preddy DFC DSC (O-430846) and Saubier’s aircraft crashed, killing him. Preddy was seriously injured but was able to bale out.

Starting on 9 September 1942, the Squadrons of 49th Fighter Group were progressively moved to Townsville, Queensland, and the air defence of Darwin was taken over by No. 77 Squadron.

On 11 September 1942, First Lieutenant Robert Gould Hazard (O-427563) (7th Fighter Squadron) went missing while ferrying a Kittyhawk aircraft from Cairns to Port Moresby.

On 14 June 1943, six members of 49th Fighter Group – Private First Class Jerome Abraham (34057460), Captain John O Berthold (O-362697), Sergeant Carl E Cunningham (16011258), Sergeant Charlie O LaRue (17031767) , Private Charles D Montgomery (18025450) and Major George N Powell (O-188378) – were killed in the crash of a 46th Troop Carrier Squadron B-17C aircraft 40-2072 aircraft near Mackay, Queensland.
